name: APS
description: Pathway where all countries fully meet their aspirational targets (incl. NDCs and net zero pledges).
scenarioOverview: The Announced Pledges Scenario (APS) shows the future of the energy sector if all countries were to hit their aspirational targets, including national and regional net zero emissions pledges, on time and in full – in addition to their legislated policies (as described in STEPS). The APS has a 50% probability to not exceed 1.7°C by 2100. The difference between the APS and the Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario highlights the ambition gap between countries’ commitments and a 1.5°C pathway.
expertRecommendation:
The APS describes a future in which all countries fully reach their aspirational climate targets, such as NDCs and other long-term strategies. It has a strong short-term baseline, as it builds on the same policies as the STEPS pathway. But it has clearer long-term assumptions. It can be useful for short-term risk analyses and long-term analyses that require a likely pathway, especially with a focus on policy considerations. Reaching a global temperature rise of 1.7°C, it can serve as a pathway for target setting, but it falls short of 1.5°C ambition.

#### Emissions
APS provides GHG emissions, including CO2, CH4 and NO2, broken down by fuel and across regions for the electricity, industry, transport and buildings sectors. Where stated, country net zero targets are integrated into the pathway. Global emissions fall by 15% between 2023 and 2030, and by 70% between 2023 and 2050, at a pace of around 4% a year (for reference, annual decrease is around 1% in STEPS and around 15% in NZE).

#### Energy demand
Oil demand decreases slightly by 2030 and almost halves by 2050, mostly driven by changes in road transportation (EV growth) and buildings (heat pump replacement). Gas demand decreases almost equally fast. Coal demand decreases by more than 57% from 2023 to 2050. Electrification of end uses is a key driver in demand shifts. Efficiency gains also play a large role in containing energy demand growth.

#### Supply assumptions
Refined materials (graphite, rare earths, cobalt, lithium, copper) and manufactured products used in the energy transition (batteries, solar PV, wind turbines, electrolysers, heat pumps) are highly concentrated in a few countries, leading to potential geopolitical tensions and other countries trying to diversify investments to counter potential supply chain bottlenecks.
Large LNG installations initially help reduce coal demand, but present other challenges in APS, where slowing demand for gas suppresses LNG export plant utilisation rates. Thus, existing LNG infrastructure and ongoing projects could turn into stranded assets under the APS.

#### Demand Shifts
APS does not model a high impact of behavioural changes on emissions reductions, as these are rarely part of NDCs and other long-term targets. This is due to the perceived unpopularity of such measures. Electrification of end-uses is a major contributing factor to growing electricity demand across transport, industry, and buildings sectors. At the same time, this shift significantly reduces overall energy demand. The increased pace of electrification in APS (through EV adoption, heat pumps, etc.) drives the electricity demand faster than in STEPS, with a still rather modest gap of 796 TWh in 2030 that grows significantly larger to 12212 TWh in 2050, highlighting the impact of long-term policies on electrification.

#### Policies
The APS includes the most recent version of NDC targets including, for example, coal phase out commitments. It also includes national power development plans, including targets for renewable energy additions or technology mix, as described in tables B.6 to B.11 of IEA WEO 2024.
The APS models a carbon price, affecting electricity, industry and energy production sectors. The carbon tax is structured in three regional tiers, based on economic strength and availability of net zero pledges. It complements the modelling of direct policy interventions to drive the transition, see table B.2.

#### Technology Costs
Costs in the power sector are broken down into capital costs (USD/kW), Fuel, CO2, and O&M costs (USD/MWh) and LCOE (USD/MWh). Wholesale fossil fuel prices are available for crude oil (USD/barrel), natural gas (USD/MBtu), steam coal (USD/ton).
Technology costs and supply assumptions are provided for the biggest markets (EU, US, India, China) in tables B.4 and B.5.

#### Technology Deployment
Technology deployment is influenced by technology costs. Solar, wind and battery storage benefit from decreasing cost trajectories reflecting global learning curves and economies of scale. APS forecasts an increase of carbon removals until 2030 (119t of CO2 removed a year), increasing to 788t of CO2 removed in 2050 – which is significantly faster than in STEPS.

#### Investment needs
The APS provides a global investment figure for the power sector split by transmission & distribution, battery storage, nuclear, wind & solar, unabated fossil fuel, and other low carbon technologies.
Unabated fossil fuels amounts to 1.2% of total power investment in 2030, down to 0.9% by 2035. Wind and solar PV investments peak at 969 billion USD in 2030, before decreasing slightly to 809 Bn USD by 2035. Investment in battery storge almost quadruples between 2023 and 2035 from 41 billion USD to 161 billion USD.

#### Infrastructure requirements
Transmission and distribution investment increased from 375 billion USD in 2023 to 905 billion USD in 2035. This investment relates to 1.6 million km of power grid replacements between 2026-2030 (constant across IEA scenarios) and 2.2 million km of extensions of the grid.

dataSource.description: The scenario data is integrated in the World Energy Outlook, a report published annually by the International Energy Agency, an inter-governmental organization in charge of assessing the state of the energy sector and forecast sector trends. Information about this pathway is drawn from [IEA World Energy Outlook](https://www.iea.org/reports/world-energy-outlook-2024).

name: STEPS
description: Shows current trends of the energy economy. Uses active policies from sectors, countries, regions.
scenarioOverview: The Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) provides a sense of the energy sector’s direction of travel today, based on the latest market data, technology costs and in-depth analysis of the prevailing policy settings in countries around the world. STEPS is complemented by APS, a scenario which assumes that countries’ aspirational targets will be met in full. The difference between STEPS and APS highlights a commitment gap.
expertRecommendation:
The STEPS scenario is a scenario highlighting legislated in-place country action. This scenario from IEA has a high-standard baseline and documents short-term action very well. It can be a good fit for short term risk analyses. However, as it does not consider long term policies, it can raise some issues for analyses focusing on a longer term. It also lacks ambition as it models 2.4°C global warming, which makes it inadequate for target setting use cases.

#### Emissions
STEPS provides GHG emissions, including CO2, CH4 and NO2, broken down by fuel and across regions for Electricity, Industry (Steel, Cement, Chemicals, Other), Transport (Road, Aviation, Shipping, Rail) and Buildings. Emissions peaks before 2030, then experience a moderate decrease of 1% a year until 2050, led by a 3% decrease in emissions from China. As a comparison with other scenarios provided by IEA, APS forecasts a 4% annual decrease after 2030, and NZE a 15% one.

#### Energy demand
The fuel demand decrease is more ambitious where low carbon technology is already available. For example, oil demand slightly diminishes in STEPS, mostly driven by changes in road transportation (EV growth) and buildings (heat pump replacement). Gas demand peaks in 2030, but the 2050 level is still higher than 2023. Coal demand decreases by 40%, and 80% of that decrease is due to power generation.

#### Supply assumptions
Refined materials (graphite, rare earths, cobalt, lithium, copper) and manufactured products (batteries, solar PV, wind, electrolysers, heat pumps) used in the energy transition are highly concentrated in a few countries, leading to potential geopolitical tensions and other countries trying to diversify investments to counter this concentration of the supply chain.
Large LNG installations initially help reduce coal demand, but lock in additional gas supply in STEPS. Legislated subsidies and implemented CO2 prices struggle to help replace gas with low-carbon technologies. 

#### Demand Shifts
STEPS assumes little impact on energy demand from behavioural shifts. Electrification of end-uses is a major contributing factor to growing electricity demand across transport, industry, and buildings sectors. At the same time, this shift significantly reduces overall energy demand. As most countries have some plan to increase electrification in the coming years, the STEPS gap in electricity generation between STEPS and APS is till very modest in 2030 at 796 TWh. This changes drastically by 2050, with 12212 TWh less electricity generated in STEPS than in APS, highlighting the short-term impact of the legislated policies in STEPS that do not match the long-term impact in APS.

#### Policies
STEPS does not include NDC targets in general but will include any legislated plan. Policies included are described in table B.6 to table B.11 of IEA WEO 2024.
The IEA also includes a CO2 price for the STEPS scenario, that covers the electricity, industrial and energy sectors. More info in table B.2.

#### Technology Costs
Costs in the power sector are broken down into capital costs (USD/kW), Fuel, CO2, and O&M costs (USD/MWh) and LCOE (USD/MWh). Wholesale fossil fuel prices are available for crude oil (USD/barrel), natural gas (USD/MBtu), steam coal (USD/ton).
Technology costs and supply assumptions are provided for the biggest markets (EU, US, India, China) in tables B.4 and B.5.

#### Technology Deployment
Technology deployment is influenced by technology costs. Solar, wind and battery storage benefit from decreasing cost trajectories reflecting global learning curves and economies of scale. STEPS forecasts a slight increase of carbon removals until 2040 (30t of CO2 removed a year), increasing to 50t of CO2 removed in 2050 – which is a slow deployment of carbon removal technologies, an average annual growth of 14%

#### Investment needs
STEPS provides a global investment figure for the power sector split by transmission & distribution, battery storage, nuclear, wind & solar, unabated fossil fuel, other low carbon technologies and other renewables. 
Unabated fossil fuels drop from 7% in 2023 to 2% of total power investment by 2030 and 2035. Wind and solar PV investments increase from 604 billion USD in 2023 to 742 billion USD in 2030, representing 45% of total power investment. In 2035, the investment in solar PV and wind is expected to return to the 2023 level. This is one of the limitations of STEPS: Due to its assumptions based on implemented policies, STEPS has a robust baseline and short-term assumptions, but it lacks credibility in the longer term, as legislations often focus on the short term. Investment in battery storage triples from 41 Bn USD in 2023 to 134 Bn USD in 2035.

#### Infrastructure requirements
Transmission and distribution investment increase from 375 billion USD in 2023 to 749 billion USD in 2035.
This investment relates to 1.6 million km of power grid replacements between 2026-2030 (constant across IEA scenarios) and 2 million km of extensions of the grid.

Information about this pathway is drawn from [IEA World Energy Outlook](https://www.iea.org/reports/world-energy-outlook-2024).
